msIdentifier.collection: Civil War & Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, Main Collection

note.p: James J. Smylie was a businessman, Confederate officer, and Methodist minister in Mississippi in the nineteenth century.

Born on October 9, 1829, in Copiah County, Mississippi, Smylie was a successful businessman and farmer active in the Methodist church. In 1861, following the outbreak of the Civil War, he was appointed Quartermaster of the Third Mississippi Infantry Regiment, and labored to acquire and disperse supplies for Confederate forces over the next few years.

After the Civil War, Smylie worked as an insurance agent and became a Methodist preacher. He died on December 31, 1880. Smylie was married to Sarah Elizabeth Stovall and had at least five children. He is buried in Rose Hill Cemetery in Quitman County, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; The Farmer’s Vindicator, Jackson, MS, May 14, 1875; “Letter from Secretary of War Judah P. Benjamin to Mississippi Governor John J. Pettus; October 31, 1861,” Civil War and Reconstruction Governors of Mississippi, mdah_75-940-04-32)
James J. Smylie belonged to the following social groups:
James B. McRae was a Confederate officer, Mississippi State Senator and Representative, and the brother of Mississippi Governor John Jones McRae.

Born on May 13, 1830 in Pascagoula, Mississippi, McRae began his political career as his brother Governor John Jones McRae's private secretary. He was also a farmer, and in 1858, he received his first nomination to enter the state legislature. In 1859, he was elected as a state Senator. During the Civil War, he served in the Confederate Army, ending the war with a rank of Colonel serving in the Third Mississippi Infantry. After the Civil War, McRae returned to Pascagoula, where he reentered state politics in the 1870s. By 1882, he was a state Representative. He served multiple terms.
McRae did not marry. He died on December 20, 1896 in Gautier, Mississippi and was buried in the McRae family cemetery in Jackson County, Mississippi.

(FindaGrave; Mississippi Free Trader, August 9, 1858; Semi-Weekly Mississippian, October 18, 1859; The Clarion Ledger, August 3, 1871; The Clarion, March 29, 1882; Mississippian, November 13, 1883; The Clarion Ledger, December 14, 1895; Census Record for Wayne, Mississippi, 1860)
James Britton McRae belonged to the following social groups:

note.p: Winfield Scott Featherston was a U.S. congressman from Mississippi and a general in the Confederate Army during the Civil War.

Born on August 8, 1820, near Murfreesboro, Tennessee, Featherston volunteered for militia service as a teenager during the Second Creek War in Alabama in 1836. After that conflict, he moved to Mississippi and studied law, becoming a practicing attorney in 1840. Soon after, Featherston became involved in local politics, and won a seat to the U.S. House of Representatives for Mississippi in 1846. He served until 1851, then returned to his home in Houston, Mississippi, after losing reelection in 1850. In 1856, he moved to Holly Springs and opened a successful law firm.

Featherston remained a political figure in Mississippi, particularly during the secession movement following Abraham Lincoln’s election to the presidency in 1860. He traveled to Kentucky, as an agent of Mississippi, to encourage secession in that state. When the war broke out in 1861, Featherston received a commission as a colonel and took command of the Seventeenth Mississippi Infantry Regiment. Sent to Virginia, he led Confederate troops at the First Battle of Bull Run and Ball’s Bluff in Virginia. He was promoted to brigadier general in March 1862 and participated in several major engagements that year, including the Seven Days Campaign outside of Richmond, the Second Battle of Bull Run, Antietam, and Fredericksburg.

In early 1863, Featherston was transferred to Mississippi. He commanded a brigade during the Vicksburg campaign, seeing combat at Champion’s Hill, and participated in the Atlanta Campaign in 1864. He remained with General John Bell Hood’s army during the disastrous campaign into Tennessee in late 1864, and commanded a brigade in General Joseph E. Johnston’s army during the final weeks of the war in the Carolinas. He surrendered to Union troops in late April 1865, was paroled shortly afterwards, and returned to Holly Springs, Mississippi.

Featherston immediately returned to politics after the war, running an unsuccessful bid for the United States Senate. He practiced law, and remained active in local political activities opposing Republican Reconstruction. In 1876, he won a seat in the Mississippi legislature and remained there until 1882, when he received an appointment as a district judge. One of his final political acts was as a delegate to Mississippi’s 1890 constitutional convention, which reinstituted many discriminatory policies against African Americans.
Featherston was married to Elizabeth McEwen and had seven children. He died in 1891 and is buried in Hill Crest Cemetery in Holly Springs, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; FindaGrave; Ben Wynne, “Winfield Scott Featherston,” Mississippi Encyclopedia)
Winfield Scott Featherston belonged to the following social groups:

note.p: Charles Clark served as Mississippi’s governor during the last two years of the Civil War. Born in Cincinnati, Ohio, on May 24, 1811, Clark later moved to Mississippi, where he became a lawyer and a state representative in the late 1830s. After successfully representing a Mississippi settler in a land dispute with members of the Choctaw Nation in the early 1840s, Clark received a large tract of land near Beulah, Mississippi, as payment. Clark eventually enlarged his property to over five thousand acres, making it one of the largest and most successful plantations in Mississippi. During this time, he married Ann Eliza Darden and between 1840 and 1852 fathered three children.

Clark volunteered for military service during the Mexican-American War in 1846 and raised a company of volunteers that was placed into the 2nd Mississippi Regiment. After its original commander resigned, Clark was elected colonel. Following the war in 1848, he returned to Mississippi resumed an interest in politics. He was selected as a delegate to a state convention in 1851 that debated the matter of secession in the wake of the Compromise of 1850, which had tried to settle a fierce dispute over the fate of slavery in territories gained by the United States from Mexico. Clark attended the convention as a Unionist, opposed to withdrawing from the Union. Developments over the next ten years changed his mind.

Clark won a seat in the Mississippi’s House of Representatives as a Whig, serving from 1856 to 1861. Following Abraham Lincoln’s election as president in 1860, Clark embraced Mississippi’s secession. When the Civil War broke out, Clark received a commission as a brigadier general in the Mississippi Militia. He later entered the Confederate Army and eventually took command of a division. Slightly wounded at the Battle of Shiloh in April 1862, he was more seriously wounded and captured during fighting at Baton Rouge, Louisiana, in August 1862. Clark spent a short time as a prisoner of war before he was paroled by Union forces.

In 1863, Clark ran for governor of Mississippi, in the wake of Confederate defeats at Vicksburg and Jackson. Clark campaigned on continued resistance to the Union and easily won the executive seat. Due to Union campaigns in Mississippi, Clark periodically moved the state government, from Jackson to Macon, then to Columbus, and back to Macon. When Confederate forces in Mississippi surrendered in May 1865, Clark instructed the state legislature to convene for a special session in Jackson. In June 1865, federal troops at Jackson arrested Clark and imprisoned him at Fort Pulaski, Georgia.

Eventually released from federal custody, Clark returned to Bolivar County, Mississippi. He quietly practiced law and served on the University of Mississippi Board of Trustees during Reconstruction. In 1876, Clark received an appointment as chancellor for the fourth judicial district. He died a year later, on December 17, 1877. Clark is buried in a family cemetery at Beulah, Mississippi.
(Wikipedia; David Sansing, “Charles Clark: Twenty-fourth Governor of Mississippi: 1863–1865,” Mississippi History Now; FindaGrave)
Charles Clark belonged to the following social groups:
Located in Hinds County, Jackson was founded in 1822 and serves as one of two county seats of Hinds County and the state capital of Mississippi. (Britannica)
Located in Madison County, Canton was incorporated in 1836 and serves as the county seat. (Britannica; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries; Rowland, Mississippi, 350)

Currently an independent city, Richmond was founded in 1737 in what was Henrico County at the time of founding and was incorporated on 1742. It became the state capital of Virginia in 1779. During the American Civil War, Richmond also served as capital of the Confederacy. On July 9, 1902, Richmond became an independent city. (Wikipedia; Atlas of Historical County Boundaries)
Located in Noxubee County, Macon was founded on August 10, 1835, and serves as the county seat. (Wikipedia; Dunbar Rowland, Mississippi, Vol. 2, pg. 158)

catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The Confederate Army was the military land force of the Confederate States of America during the American Civil War. Known also as the Confederate States Army or Southern Army, it was established by the Provisional Confederate Congress in February 1861 and fell under the authority of Confederate President Jefferson Davis. Modeled after the U.S. Army of the 19th century, the Confederate Army technically fell into two categories: a small regular army of professional officers and soldiers (the Army of the Confederate States of America) and a much larger, temporary force of citizen soldiers intended to exist only for the duration of the war (the Provisional Army of the Confederate States). In reality, the Confederacy’s regular army never fully developed and the overwhelming majority of Confederate soldiers served in the provisional force. The distinction between the two played little role during military operations and all were generally considered to be part of the overall Confederate Army.

As many as 1,000,000 soldiers served in the Confederate Army between 1861 and 1865, although not all at one time. Most were volunteers, however, the Confederate government instituted a conscription (or draft) in April 1862—the first in U.S. or Confederate history—to increase the size of the Confederacy’s military force and encourage voluntary enlistment. The government passed two more conscription acts over the next two years. More than ten percent of the men who served in Confederate ranks were drafted.

Over ninety percent of soldiers in the Confederate Army were native-born white men. Nine percent were foreign-born white men. Several Native American units—particularly from the Cherokee, Creek, and Choctaw tribes—served within the Confederate military, especially in the trans-Mississippi theatre. The Confederate military heavily relied upon the forced labor of enslaved African Americans for building fortifications and carrying out menial tasks, and the Confederate government did not formally allow African Americans (free or slave) to join the army until a last minute desperate measure passed the Confederate Congress in March 1865, only weeks before the end of the war. Only around two hundred enslaved soldiers were organized into service, but they were not sent into combat.

By the time the last Confederate soldiers surrendered to Union forces in June 1865, nearly 100,000 had been killed in combat or succumbed to wounds, more than 160,000 had died of disease, and roughly 30,000 had died in prison camps. (Wikipedia)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America. Army--Featherston's Brigade
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: Featherston's Brigade was organized in June 1862 under the command of Brig. Gen. Winfield Scott Featherston. It served in the Eastern, Western, and Trans-Mississippi Theaters under the Army of Mississippi and Gen. Leonidas Polk's Army. Divisions of the unit were also commanded by Col. Mellon, Lt. Col. McRae, and Maj. Martin A. Oatis. (Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 488, 529, 537, 692)

catDesc.term: Confederate States of America. Army. Mississippi. Infantry Regiment, 3rd
catDesc.note:
Categories:
Military Units -- Federal Level: Confederate States Military

gloss.p: The 3rd Regiment, Mississippi Infantry (Confederate) was organized in the spring of 1861 in Clarke County, Mississippi under the command of Col. John B. Deason and served in the Western Theater under Hebert's and Featherston's brigades in the Department of Mississippi and East Louisiana and the Army of Tennessee. It was later commanded by Col. Thomas A. Mellon, Lt. Col. Samuel M. Dyer, and Capts. O. H. Johnston and John Saucier. It was consolidated with the 33rd and 40th Infantry Regiments to form the 3rd Regiment, Mississippi Consolidated Infantry on April 9, 1865 in Johnston County, North Carolina under the command of Col. James M. Stigler. (Howell, Jr., Military History of Mississippi, 11; Rowland, Official and Statistical Register of Mississippi, 533-540; National Park Service-Battle Units)

div.fw: Letter from Lieutenant Colonel James B. McRae to Mississippi Governor Charles Clark; December 29, 1863
div.p: I have seen capt Smylie and we have arranged matters. Whether you accept his proposition or mine we will operate under the same contract. After our conversation on Saturday last I concluded to alter the proposition I submitted to you and to leave out what you regarded as an objectionable feature. But in calling at Your office on Sunday I did not find you in. Enclosed you will find the proposition as susequently drawn off by me. I should be glad to hear from you at Canton as soon as you hear from Richmond

Jas. B. McRae
Lt col. 3d missi regt
Featherston's Brigade
Canton Missi
